reviewText: This game rocked the gaming industry near 1992 for the Amiga as it was a great and challenging hardcore game. The other ports added some additional features and Health Points, which wasn't featured on the Original Amiga version. You should also check Chris Huelsbeck's soundtracks as he is one of Amiga's legendary composer.

reviewText:
I also covered this game on YouTube: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GL-keuI9nso

This is an old-school platformer mash-up title that many probably haven't heard of. It was more popular in Europe but not so much in North America. It blends together side-scrolling action, top-down action and shoot em' up levels into the same game, something very different and ambitious for the time. None of these are shining examples of their respective genres but they're all competently done. There's a lot of content here compared to many 90s era platformers, especially PC platformers. This game is rock hard though and only suited for those who enjoy a significant challenge and/or want to practice a lot to iterate their progress.

Unfortunately, this collection is a technical mess and isn't even worth $5 in the state Piko Interactive shipped it in, especially since as of this writing, they seemed to have stopped supporting or talking about it. It includes the MS-DOS and SNES versions of this game, as well as an enhanced" SNES version
date: which is essentially a ROM hack that adds more life points and removes the double parallax scrolling which is hard on the eyes. Unreleased Genesis and NES versions were promised to be added as free DLC but these are nowhere to be seen and status is unknown.\n\nThe MS-DOS version uses the DOSBox emulator and is improperly configured when first installed from Steam. In order to get the digitised sound effects
recommended: you have to manually edit the DOSBox configuration file (instructions are in the Steam forums.) It also runs at a very inconsistent frame rate with awful screen tearing
hoursPlayed: even on my overclocked Core i7 machine. Other DOSBox games which are properly configured run like butter on this machine. This has never been fixed. You're charging money to provide the optimal way to play this game. If your users have to fix it for you
voteText: you shouldn't be charging for it.\n\nThe SNES versions use a re-badged implementation of what looks like the Snes9x emulator and while it runs at a much better frame rate and with better sound
helpfulPercent: it doesn't have proper XInput support. Trying to use an Xbox One controller results in the game thinking that B is being constantly pressed and even after rebinding the controls manually
votesHelpful: I couldn't fix it. Playing with an old Xbox 360 controller worked fine and the DOS version of the game works fine with an Xbox One controller. Unacceptable in a 2015 release.\n\nI would have refunded this game if I hadn't had it in my collection for months before I finally got around to playing it. Jim Power is an interesting historical series that platformer fans will like but in this state
votesTotal: with the lacking promised content and near silence from Piko Interactive for the last several months
votesFunny: you should not buy this package. If they ever get around to fixing it
commentsCount: optimising it and adding in the promised missing content
column16: maybe then but not before. This is the last thing I'll be buying from this company."

reviewText:
Jim Power - The Lost Dimension isn't new its a re-release and you get 3 different versions of the game.  You get the DOS, SNES original and a SNES enhanced version.  Essentially the enhanced version just uses filters to give it a more HD look and the SNES Original is a less defined version that you remember playing on the SNES.

There is a minor issue that is fixed by manually changing the graphics settings to higher performance as well as turning on V-Sync which will fix the problems with screen tearing.  Okay so how about the game play well it features two different genre's in one game.  You get  action sidescrolling platforming and a side scrolling shmup which is much like your favorite arcade counterparts.

The great part of this is that the game has an amazing difficulty setting but the DOS version and SNES are different.  The DOS version is a lot slower which makes it a lot easier and the SNES version is a lot faster and is a lot more difficult.  But hey both games are still quite difficult its just I find the DOS version a lot more easy to handle.

The music in the game is outstanding and if you know Chris Huelsback you'll know he has done music for a lot of classics which include Turricane, The Great Giana Sisters and he is now producing new music for newer games like The Giana Sisters Twisted Dreams and more so check him out.  I usually don't know how to review sound effects but hey they sound great for the 16bit genre of gaming with all the classic slashing sounds and explosion sounds you remember.

I haven't fully completed the game and its one of those games your going to have a very hard time completing but hopefully the DOS version will make things a lot more easier for you.  Its still a very fun game and something you should have in your collection if your a fan of retro gaming.

Check out https://www.pikointeractive.com/ for more information on some new and amazing classic games.

reviewText: They should teach Jim Power at whatever place they teach kids how to make games these days - because Jim Power is hilariously bad. It screams I want to be a japanese console game so bad" but has all the weaknesses of typical homecomputer games of the late 80ies and early 90ies. Everything is wrong with this game and unnecessarily so.\n\nThink of a very linear
date: very ♥♥♥♥♥♥ Turrican (with a bit of Gods and other clunky
recommended: western character-action games added to the mix) and you are on the right track what Jim Power actually feels like. Now imagine a presentation with the worst parallax scrolling and acid-trip like colors while Chris Hülsbeck music is blasting from your speakers

But each of these segments is as horribly broken as the sidescrolling bits and demanding insane precision while navigating pixel perfectly through hitbox-hell

column17: why am I giving it a thumbs up? Because this one of the greatest ♥♥♥♥♥♥ games - a piece of history and a timeless lesson in how to NOT make a character action game. You can learn so much from this prime example of bad design that is so complete in its craptasticness. And besides

reviewText:
Jim Power is not a very good game, yet it is still worth playing for it's quirky charms (and yes, excellent soundtrack.)

I definitely admire Piko's effort to make the stupendously awful SNES version *somewhat* playable, and I think they've actually succeeded. That said, the game is still more suited for a long, exacting and gruesome game design autopsy rather than any actual jump-and-shoot 16-bit fun; but that's at least a possibility now. Don't even bother with the SNES original unless you have a nearby toilet or sink to vomit into.

Once you've had your fill of laughing at all the hilariously emasculating ways ol' Jim bites it on just the first stage (death by water droplet, death by moist dog nose, etc.) in that, you can safely move on to the DOS version, which is not only graphically superior, it's infinitely closer to a polished and playable game. It's still quirky, odd and a bit off-kilter; but there's less annoying obstacles in the way of your potential platforming fun.

I also really have to commend Piko just for offering multiple ports of JP - it shouldn't be lost on younger generations that the same game was often wildly different on varying home computers and consoles. Thanks for giving customers some bang for their buck in a retro re-release! :)
